Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of this project is to artificial chromosome technology in plants. Artificial chromosomes have the potential to stack genes of benefit to agriculture and basic plant genomics studies on an independent chromosome that can be made to specification. Procedures to add new genes to pre-existing artificial chromosome platforms will be developed that can continue to make amendments in perpetuity. Secondly, methods will be tested that allow much larger numbers of genes to be added to a minichromosome in a single increment than is currently possible. Thirdly, the combination of artificial chromosomes with haploid breeding to introduce the minichromosomes into multiple new varieties more efficiently will be developed. Fourthly, a test of pollen selection to maximize the transmission of artificial chromosomes from one generation to the next will be conducted. Artificial or engineered minichromosomes have the potential to provide a pre-determined site of transgene integration into a plant genome rather than the random nature of plant transformation that is currently used. The targeted insertion will avoid the potential mutagenic effect and gene silencing that often results from uncontrolled integrations. Moreover, the potential now exists that many different genes determining several plant characteristics can be transformed at once onto a minichromosome that can be further modified and that is independent of the normal chromosomes. With the use of artificial chromosomes it should be possible to introduce whole biochemical pathways to add new properties to plants that would facilitate maximizing the ultimate yield or to use plants as factories for the inexpensive production of useful proteins or metabolites. For basic studies, artificial chromosomes provide the means to generate chromosomes to specification that will facilitate the study of chromosome behavior and gene expression among other subjects.

The amount of arable land on earth has been static for some time but the global population continues to increase. If the world standard of living is to remain as is or improve, the amount of food produced by agricultural endeavors will need to increase over the coming decades. Many new developments will be needed to address this issue but novel means of manipulating plant genomes is thought to be a major contributor to this effort. The development of plant artificial chromosome platforms and their enhancement might help with this problem. The procedures developed should be easily adapted to other plant species and thus can serve as a model system for transfer to them. Training will involve diverse undergraduate and graduate students in plant genomics and biotechnology. Information about this project and its outcomes can be accessed at the project website (http://maizeminichromosomes.missouri.edu) and MaizeGDB. These include detailed information about project objectives, results, participants, publications as well as biological resources produced such as vectors and maize lines and the protocols used to generate them. In addition, links to YouTube videos illustrating the techniques involved in the project will be accessible through the project website, MaizeGDB and ResearchGate (http://www.researchgate.net/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the development of artificial chromosome in maize. Such chromosomes are independent of the normal chromosomes and are designed to accept new genes that confer novel properties to corn plants. Two systems were developed for the addition of combinations of genes that might confer multiple traits to maize. One system was designed to combine individual genes on the order of 15 kilobase pairs of DNA each in subsequent additions to the chromosome. A second system was developed for the addition of large cargo to the artificial chromosome on the order of over 100 kilobases of DNA. Several tests of the system indicate that the frequency of integrations is extremely high and greatly exceeds the usual frequencies of transgene transformation of maize. The target sites for incoming DNA, the carrier constructs for adding new genes, and the site specific recombinase enzymes to catalyze the integrations into the target sites were all found to be functional in maize. All reactions needed for insertion by recombination were shown to occur and were validated by DNA sequence analysis. For the large cargo system, a supernumerary B chromosome was truncated by a transgene that carried a target site for acceptance of each large cargo. Thus, it can serve as a foundational chromosome to continure to add new genes, groups of genes, or chromosomal segments with sequential recombination events. A proof of concept that B chromosomes incorporated into haploid inducer lines could be transferred to haploids as a means to introduce transgenes into completely homozygous lines was conducted in the project. The transfer is at approximately 1/25 haploids. The demonstration that B chromosomes can be transferred to haploids at a workable frequency indicates that artificial chromosomes could potentially be placed with the included cargo into any maize line followed by chromosomal doubling. This process would allow the introduction of the assembled artificial chromosome carrying genes for multiple traits into any desired variety of maize. In addition to the production of artificial chromosomes, the systems developed could be used for simply combining multiple genes or groups of genes at target sites in the genome with the initial transformation of such target sites. All of the constructs should be able to be used in any other plant species that is transformable, greatly expanding the use of this highly efficient system for placing transgenes into genomes and for their use in plant synthetic biology. In terms of broader impacts, the project trained four graduate students and one undergraduate in plant molecular genetics. Protocols for chromosomal analysis, chromosomal truncation, the handling of telomere sequences, and the handling of large cargo constructs were published for use by the community. Instructional videos were produced for Youtube. The constructs and materials produced provide a means to place at very high efficiency multiple transgenes at predetermined positions in the genome that are previously known to support activity of transgenes. Artificial chromosomes will permit the combination of genes or genomic segments to a chromosome that is independent of the normal chromosomes. Ultimately, these materials should allow the introduction of multiple genes for diverse traits to a common independent chromosome that can be placed in any maize variety to enhance its properties.
